title: The Fine Line Between Genius and Madness
body:
I think it is coming, carved the boy onto his arm, the blade a silver flash against paper pale skin. No, no, no… I think it has always been here, and I am just beginning to realize.

The scarlet blood welled up, frothing, seething, a reminder of what he was trying so desperately to forget.

⮍

When he was young, just a toddler, the Madness was subdued. Singing and surging at the edges of his vision. A separate entity, eating away at his figure until he blurred. It was a vaguely ecstatic feeling, really, letting the insanity murmur lullabies, letting it build skeletal butterflies out of thin air.

⮍

When he got older, the Madness grew upon him, enveloped him, shrieking, screeching. It was the shadow that covered him like a mask, and the harder he fought, the more it bled into him, tainting his innocence with dark creeping tendrils. Alone he was just a boy, just a weak little boy, and with the Madness he was brilliant, blazing, incandescent with the radiance of everything he had never been. It was such a heady high, he didn’t realize: the brightest candles burn out the fastest.

⮍

When the Madness crept back behind the curtains -- as it always did -- the snake whispering ceased for a few dreaded hours, and for what felt like an eon he’d lie stiff like a corpse, needing to spit something out but the words refusing to assemble inside his head, the absolute nothing of humanity threatening to strangle him. He’d feel the weight of his uselessness like an anvil on his chest, ready to snap his ribs, unfinished thoughts whirling round like death sentences. Come back, he’d beseech the Madness, desperate, cracking, please don’t leave me. He was nothing without the Madness, which was also nothing without him.

It was… what had that book called it? … a symbiotic relationship.

⮍

His mother suspected drugs.

He knew she did -- he figured out during one of those periods when he was first getting onto his high and everything was technicolor, bursting with vivid shades, almost painful in its beauty.

Ruffled bed sheet, she checked under my bed, closet left a sliver open, she rifled through there too, she thinks it’s heroin, she thinks it’s cocaine, ha! so stupid, so uninspired, someone should slice off their eyelids with a pen-knife just so they’ll be forced to open their eyes and see…

No, this wasn’t drugs, rather close but no cigar, and it was so obvious that it wasn’t, simply because drugs were something to be hidden. Concealed.

Small parcels you took from the shade-faced man in the alley, the frantic yet silent easing of a needle into bruise-blue veins. A high that was more from the delicious illegality of the act than the chemical part of it.

But he was different.

He could not hide what he had; the Madness did not like that.

And what was he without his Madness?

He lived off of what it gave him -- fantastical daydreams, balanced out by earth-shattering nightmares, food an unnecessary nuisance. He ran on gasoline.

The first couple times the Madness hit him, it was something so razor sharp. He saw everything, catalogued it as a scientist would a dissected specimen, spoke like he’d die if the words didn’t spill past his lips. It was excruciatingly exquisite, agonizingly alluring.

For a while.

Nothing good can last long.

He was a being of raw energy, drowning in his own light, bottled up inside this cage of bone and meat and wanting nothing more than to explode into something true and spectacular. The world would tremble underneath his feet, and he’d scratch at this disgusting body of his, this beautiful fragile oh-so-breakable thing, this frail little cage that he loathed.

He would shudder back with a gasp, the glow in his brain receding, receding, until he was left cold and shivering on a comfortless bed, grasping for the last vestiges like the junkie he’d forbidden himself to be.

⮍

When he set his mind to something, he’d trek across universes to get it, and with the tinny little voice at the base of his skull he was invincible.

So when the others got too inquisitive or too annoying or he just got too damn bored he’d find a way to get rid of them and that was that.

It was always something indirect -- a carefully placed rock sending a childhood bully tumbling into the road, or a deer lumbering across the street, causing a car to skid off an incline.

It would always work, it had to.

God, if you were into that sort of nonsense, supposedly never turned his back on his devoted followers.

He had a different religion, a higher power that licked slowly at the edges of his conscience, wearing it down like a jawbreaker.

The newspapers painted headlines in shades of fibs and drama, but the core of lies was always a tiny nugget of truth.

A saying once preached that no-one would know of the perfect crime.

No one did.

⮍

I am dead. They cannot kill me, because I was never alive. I decay inside this prison of gristle and rot.

They’re all liars, every one of the others -- pebbles believing themselves to be marble statues, something that could once have been great, slowly crumbling from the weight of their potential.

⮍

The last day, he holed himself up in his room with a machete.

I think it is coming, carved the boy onto his china-skinned arm, the blade a silver flash against paper pale. No, no, no… I think it has always been here, and I am just beginning to realize.
author: GlobalStrategy
